title: Designing a $100,000 Portfolio for Retirement in Your 50s
subtitle: Simple strategies for investing wisely as you approach retirement.
content:
Designing a $100,000 Portfolio for Retirement in Your 50s

I'm Tyler, a former financial advisor and portfolio manager. I make financial content for free so you don't have to pay for it.

1. Invest $40,000 into SCHD

This is Schwab's Dividend Stock ETF, holding about 100 of the best dividend payers like Chevron, Pfizer, and Coca-Cola. The current yield is around 3.5%. Importantly, these are not just income stocks; they're dividend growers. Over the last decade, SCHD has returned about 12% annually, offering both income and projected growth. That’s my kind of investment!

2. Invest $30,000 into VOO or SPLG

These are classic S&P 500 funds. As you might still live for another 40 years, you'll need growth. Keep it simple; you don’t need to swing for the fences at this stage.

3. Invest $20,000 into BND or FBND

These are total bond market funds. As of year-end 2025, yields are decent again, around 4% or 5%. Bonds often stabilize your portfolio, especially when stocks inevitably crash. While the old rule might suggest an age-based percentage in bonds, 20%-30% in bonds during your 50s is just fine for most of us.

4. Invest $10,000 in a money market fund

Consider VMFXX or SPAXX, which are earning about 4%. This serves as your 'sleep at night' money. It provides you with added liquidity, so if the market crashes right when you retire, you're not forced to sell stocks at a loss.
